list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The Burns, Gordons and Longstaff families make meal plans for their households. The table below shows the amount of carbohydrate, fat and protein, all measured in grams, consumed by the family over a single day. The table also shows the daily calories, measured in kcal, this equates to.

Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the amount of calories, in kcal, for $1$ g of carbohydrate, fat and protein respectively.


Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $x$, $y$ and $z$ that represents the information in the table above. [2]



Find the values $x$, $y$ and $z$. [2]



The Howe family also plans meals. The table below shows the amount of carbohydrates, fat and protein consumed by the family over a single day.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/350ffb2d-5f7c-4d42-9455-67a41e1ff452/images/a0f40aa2-3fd5-4e46-b963-a74843eb2043/1111b.JPG)



Calculate the daily calories for the Howe family. [2]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$859x1026x595x​+++​164y231y217y​+++​296z414z112z​===​656185434980​​​$$$
$$$​A2​$$$

$$$CarbohydratesFatProtein​:3.70 grams per calorie​:9.67 grams per calorie​:6.07 grams per calorie​​A2​$$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
A toy rocket is fired, from a platform, vertically into the air, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t)=at2+bt+c$, where $a,b,c∈R$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bb0065fc-bc20-4898-a580-9d8d84f4cc81/images/26a3d948-9010-49f6-b623-7aac14c767bf/rocket.png)


After $2$ second, the rocket is $28.3$ m above the ground; after $4$ seconds, $25.6$ m; after $5$ seconds, $14.7$ m.




Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$.


Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3]





Find the height, above the ground, of the platform. [1]



Find the time it takes for the rocket to hit the ground. [2]
list.markScheme:
We have

$$$4a16a25a​+++​2b4b5b​+++​ccc​===​28.325.614.7​​​A2​$$$

Using a G.D.C. we find $a=−3.18,b=17.8,c=5.53​$

$$$​A1​$$$


Evaluating $s(t)$ at $t=0$, we obtain the height of the platform


$$$s(0)​=−3.18(0)2+17.8(0)+5.53=5.53 m​​A1​$$$

Solving the equation $s(t)=0$ for $t$, we find
$$$−3.18t2+17.8t+5.53t​=0=−0.295...,5.8925...[by using G.D.C.]​M1​$$$
The value of $t$ must be positive
$$$t=5.89 seconds​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
An owl takes off from from a tree branch and flies higher into the sky. Its height above the ground after $t$ seconds, where $t≥0$, is given by $s(t)=at3+bt2+ct+d$, where $a,b,c,d∈R$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f2f10540-8736-484c-b76e-293673a1a920/images/e10ba209-e2d4-4ca9-a89f-fc01ced21fb2/owl.png)


Initially the owl is $12$ metres above the ground.

Write down the value of $d$. [1]


After $1$ second, the owl is $19.8$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $34.5$ m; after $4$ seconds, $22.8$ m.




Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$.


Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$.  [3]





After some time the owl reaches a maximum height. At this time it spots some prey at ground level and then immediately swoops down to catch it.




Find the maximum height of the owl above the ground as it spots the prey.


Find the time it catches the prey. [2]
list.markScheme:
$d=12$ m

$$$​A1​$$$



We have

$$$a8a64a​+++​b4b16b​+++​c2c4c​+++​121212​===​19.834.522.8​​​M1A1​$$$

Using a G.D.C. we can find the values of the parameters, $a=−2.575$, $b=11.175$ and $c=−0.8$.\[6pt]
These values can be rounded to three significant figures giving
$a=−2.58,b=11.2,c=−0.8​$

$$$​A1​$$$




The coordinates of the local maximum of when the owl spots the prey is $(2.857...,40.96...)$.
The $y−$coordinate of this local maximum gives the height of the owl as it spots the prey.\[6pt]
Hence the owl is at a height of $41.0m​$.
$$$​A1​$$$


The owl catches the prey when the height of the owl is zero, i.e. $s(t)=0$ when $t>0$. This can be found with a G.D.C., $(4.501...,0)$. With the $x−$coordinate being the time.
Hence the owl catches the prey at $t=4.50s​$.
$$$​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Coral is a wildlife expert who tags  flying fish and records their movement using an electronic device.
The tagging device tells her the height of a fish relative to the water level, at any given time.
She knows that the fish swim mostly in the water, but occasionally they fly (jump!) out of the water.
The height is measured in metres and the time in seconds. If the height is negative the fish is under the water, if the height is positive the fish is flying.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99db50ab-81ea-421b-8f20-21b4669fedcd/images/70f02a92-7870-456a-abea-c262c3ce2d2b/seagull.png)


Coral notices one particular fish as it flies out of the water. The moment it re-enters the water the device begins tracking its height.
At $2$ seconds the fish is at a height of $−2.8$m; at $5$ seconds the fish is at a height of $−2$m and at $11$ seconds the fish is also at a height of $−2$m.
The height of the fish can be expressed as $H(t)=at3+bt2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d∈R$.




Write down the value of $d$.


Using the information given write down three equations involving $a$, $b$ and $c$.


Solve the system of equations to find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4]





From previous research, Coral knows that if a fish is flying for more than $1$ second then a seagull will attempt to catch it.

Use a justification to explain why a seagull will attempt to catch this fish. [4]


At $t=9$s a seagull begins swooping down to catch the fish.
Its height is given by $b(t)=−1.5t2+27t−118$.




Find the height at which the bird catches the fish.


Interpret the answer in the context of the problem. [4]
list.markScheme:
$d=0$.
$$$​A1​$$$


Using the information given we have
$$$8a125a1331a​+++​4b25b121b​+++​2c5c11c​===​−2.8−2−2​​​M1A1​$$$


Solving on a G.D.C. we have $a=−0.0330,b=0.564 and c=−2.40​$.
$$$​A1​$$$




When the fish is out of the water it is said to be flying. Hence we need to identify when $H(t)>0$.
$$$​(M1)​$$$
We can sketch $H(t)=−0.0330t3+0.564t2−2.40t$ on a G.D.C.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99db50ab-81ea-421b-8f20-21b4669fedcd/images/954048de-59b6-4d32-b5eb-dc27f1407e86/an1.png)


The difference between the two roots $x1​$ and $x2​$ is the time when $H(t)>0$. This can be seen on the graph above as the length of the red line.
$$$​M1​$$$
Hence, the total time out of the water is given by
$$$​=x2​−x1​=9.0909...−8[using G.D.C.]=1.09 seconds​A1​$$$
As $1.09>1​$ we can say that a seagull will attempt to catch the fish.
$$$​R1​$$$


The bird catches the fish when the $b(t)=H(t)$ and $t>9$.
$$$​(M1)​$$$
Using a G.D.C. we can show to motion of the bird, in blue, using the model $b(t)$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99db50ab-81ea-421b-8f20-21b4669fedcd/images/b3837cf2-870c-4368-bdc5-34bdc0a05ee2/an2.png)


The point $C$, $t>9$, is when the bird catches the fish.
The coordinates of point $C$ are $(10.893...,−1.8735...)$.
$$$​A1​$$$
Hence the bird catches the fish at a height of $−1.87m​$.
$$$​A1​$$$


The height is negative, this means the bird catches the fish
$1.87m below the surface of the water​$
$$$​R1​$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Consider the quadratic function $f(x)=ax2+bx+c$. The graph of
$y=f(x)$ is shown in the diagram below. The vertex of the graph has
coordinates $R(m,−9)$.
The graph intersects the $x$-axis at two points; $P(−4,0)$ and
$Q(2,0)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b09e52c7-02f5-45a2-96f9-ab7aa4138a3b/images/a78c2481-ec6d-41fe-99c5-6ab402d1c48c/b188999a18650c4961f7def85ea1bfd8a1276fc9.svg)




Find the value of $m$. [1]



Find the values of $a$, $b$, and $c$.[5]



Write down the equation of the axis of symmetry of the graph.
[1]
list.markScheme:
The point $(m,0)$ is halfway between P and Q (symmetrical nature of
quadratic graphs). Since the total length from P to Q is 6 units,
the length from P to $(m,0)$ is 3 units. Therefore,
$$$​m=−1​​$$$


Using $y=ax2+bx+c$ and the 3 coordinates we know the graph passes
through, we can set up three equations, as follows
$$$00​=a(−4)2+b(−4)+cUsing P(−4,0)=16a−4b+c​(1)$$$
$$$00​=a(2)2+b(2)+cUsing Q(2,0)=4a+2b+c​(2)$$$
$$$−9−9​=a(−1)2+b(−1)+cUsing R(−1,−9)=a−b+c​(3)$$$
We can now use a GDC to solve equations
$(1)$, $(2)$, and $(3)$. We get
$$$a=1,b=2,andc=−8​$$$


The axis of symmetry of the graph is the line that splits the
quadratic graph in half, passing through the turning point. Hence,
the equation of this line is
$$$x=−1​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The graph below shows the amount of money $M$ (in thousands of dollars), in the account of a contractor,  where $t$ is the time in months since he opened the account.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/17bf7bc4-74b6-43c8-9455-a3c62c7a5acb/images/be163de5-68b0-49ca-94db-b870708b6869/AI1015a.PNG)



Write down one characteristic of the graph which suggests that a cubic function might be an appropriate model for the amount of money in the account. [1]


The equation of the model can be expressed as $M(t)=at3+bt2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d∈R$. It is given that the graph of the model passes through the following points.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/17bf7bc4-74b6-43c8-9455-a3c62c7a5acb/images/5c93f523-f86a-4794-ac51-31c1c41cc134/AI1015b.PNG)






State the value of $d$.


Using the values in the table, write down three equations in $a$, $b$, and $c$.


By solving the system of equations from part (ii), find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4]





If $M$ has a negative value, the contractor is in debt.

Use the model from part (b) to find the number of months the contractor expects to be in debt. Give your answer to the nearest month. [3]
list.markScheme:
The graph of $M$ has exactly one maximum point and one minimum point.




From the table, we have $M(0)=1$. Substituting the value $t=0$ into the model we have
$$$M(0)​=a(0)3+b(0)2+c(0)+d=d​$$$
We have $M(0)=1$ and $M(0)=d$ and therefore $d=1​$


Using the values given in the table, and part (i), we have
$$$M(1)M(2)M(3)​=a(1)3+b(1)2+c(1)+1=2=a(2)3+b(2)2+c(2)+1=−3=a(3)3+b(3)2+c(3)+1=4​$$$
Hence, the linear system for variables $a$, $b$ and $c$ is
$$$​⎩⎨⎧​a+b+c=18a+4b+2c=−427a+9b+3c=3​​​$$$


Using G.D.C. to solve the linear system found in part (ii), we get
$$$​a=3,b=−12, and c=10​​$$$




Using the G.D.C. to graph the polynomial $M(t)=3t3−12t2+10t+1$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/17bf7bc4-74b6-43c8-9455-a3c62c7a5acb/images/4b085cb1-6cef-4368-855b-cb6f761ecd30/AI1015c.PNG)


Hence, the time the contractor is in debt equals the time between point A and point B:
$$$Time in debt​=2.738−1.352=1.386​$$$
To the nearest month, the contractor expects to be in debt for $one month.​$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The graph below shows the profit $P$ (in thousands of dollars), that business A makes,  where $t$ is the time in months since January 1st.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/c66ce31d-cb54-4bbd-848a-ef2cd4a05037/ai1106e.PNG)



Write down one characteristic of the graph which suggests that a cubic function might be an appropriate model for the business profit. [1]


The model can be expressed as $P(t)=at3+bt2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d∈R$. It is given that the graph of the model passes through the following points.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/ef93a216-cfb9-450f-a315-71dbbb9af371/ai1106b.PNG)






State the value of $d$.


Using the values in the table, write down three equations in $a$, $b$, and $c$.


By solving the system of equations from part (ii), find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4]





If $P$ has a negative value, business A is losing money. The owner has decided they will not open during the corresponding time next year.

Use the model from part (b) to find the approximate dates during which business A will not open next year. [4]


Business B has a profit function given by $P(t)=−0.1t2+1.2t$, for $0≤t≤12$.

Determine the total amount of time for which business B is more profitable than business A. [3]
list.markScheme:
$The graph of P has exactly one maximum point and one minimum point.​$
$$$​A1$$$




From the table, we have $P(0)=2$. Substituting the value $t=0$ into the model we have
$$$P(0)​=a(0)3+b(0)2+c(0)+d=d​$$$
We have $P(0)=2$ and $P(0)=d$ and therefore $d=2​$
$$$​A1$$$


Using the values given in the table, and part (i), we have
$$$P(4)P(8)P(12)​=a(4)3+b(4)2+c(4)+2=4=a(8)3+b(8)2+c(8)+2=−6=a(12)3+b(12)2+c(12)+2=8​(M1)​$$$
Hence, the linear system for variables $a$, $b$ and $c$ is
$$$​⎩⎨⎧​64a+16b+4c=2512a+64b+8c=−81728a+144b+12c=6​​​$$$
$$$​A1$$$


Using G.D.C. to solve the linear system found in part (ii), we get
$$$​a=0.09375,b=−1.5, and c=5​​A1​$$$




Using the G.D.C. to graph the polynomial $P(t)=0.09375t3−1.5t2+5t+2$,
$$$​(M1)$$$
we can find the zeroes of the function.
$$$​(A1)$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/f941dc8d-5e1b-4150-9755-fcb2277ef68a/ai1106c.PNG)


Hence, the time that business A will not open is from $t=5.407$ months until $t=10.95$ months after January 1st. Note that $t=5.407$ equates to a date in June, which has 30 days, and $t=10.95$ equates to a date in November, which also has 30 days.
$$$0.407×300.95×30​=12.21=28.5​(M1)​$$$
Business A will be closed from approximately $June 13th until November 29th.​$
$$$​A1$$$


Using the G.D.C., we can graph the polynomial for business B (shown in red), $P(t)=−0.1t2+1.2t$, on the same axes as the polynomial for business A. We can then find the points of intersection.
$$$​(M1)$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/94fdb4ca-3aad-4323-a785-bc1185c059fb/ai1106d.PNG)


Business B is more profitable for $4.270≤t≤11.11$. We have
$$$11.11−4.270​=6.84​(M1)​$$$
$Business B is more profitable for approximately 6.84 months.​$
$$$​A1$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The Burj Khalifa, located in Dubai, is the tallest building in the
world. It has a height of $830 m$ and has a square base that
covers a floor area of $556 m×556 m$. A tourism
shop located near the building sells souvenirs of the tower, which sit
inside glass pyramids, as illustrated by the diagram below. The souvenir
tower is an accurate scale replica of the actual tower.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/490aa73b-d0b9-484e-9cf9-6362beb9193f/75dbfe1df45464ae26235a84b47e84fedd3f43ea.svg)


The scaled model of Burj Khalifa has a base area of
$20 cm×20 cm$. The height and base area
dimensions of the glass pyramid are 10% larger than the model.




Find the height of the souvenir tower, in cm, correct to the
nearest mm.


Find the volume of the glass pyramid, rounding your answer
correct to the nearest cubic centimetre. [5]





The shop owner aims to maximise profits from selling the souvenirs. The
more the owner orders from the manufacturer, the cheaper the souvenirs
are to buy. However, if too many are ordered, profits may decrease due
to surplus stock unsold.
The number of souvenirs ordered from previous years and the resulting
profits are shown in the following table.
QuantityProfit($)$5000$$35000$$10000$$95500$$13000$$116500$
The shop owner decides to fit a cubic model of the form
$$$P(x)=ax3+bx2+cx+d$$$
to model the profit, $P$, for $x$ thousand
souvenirs ordered.


Explain why $d=0$.[1]



Construct three linear equations to solve for $a$, $b$ and $c$, and
hence write down the completed function $P(x)$. [5]



Find $P′(x)$.[2]



Find, to the nearest hundred souvenirs, the optimal number of
souvenirs the owner should buy to maximise profit, and the resulting
profit from this number. [4]
list.markScheme:
The height $(hm​)$ of the model can be calculated by
$$$hm​​=height of Burj Khalifa×scale factor=83000×5560020​[all values in cm]≈29.9 cm​​$$$


Let $x$ be the side length of the base and $h$ be the height of
the glass pyramid. Since the dimensions of glass pyramid are
$10%$ larger than the model, we get
$$$xh​=20+20(0.1)=22 cm=29.9+29.9(0.1)≈32.9 cm​$$$




![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/19611668-b3b5-4172-ace2-b6f0010e0b75/c16aa6b415e3ff65a129bf040b3ec43c108d55ec.svg)


The volume $(V)$ of the glass pyramid can therefore be calculated by
$$$V​=31​×x2×h=31​×(22)2×(32.9)≈5308 cm3​​$$$


If zero souvenirs are ordered (i.e. $x=0$), there won't be any
souvenirs to sell. Hence, the profit, $P$, will also be zero.
$$$P(0)=0, hence d=0​$$$


Since $x$ is in thousands, we have
$$$P(5)P(10)P(13)​=53a+52b+5c=35000(1)=103a+102b+10c=95500(2)=133a+132b+13c=116500(3)​$$$
Using
G.D.C. to solve the equations $(1)$, $(2)$ and $(3)$, we get
$$$a=−262295​,b=2647685​, and c=13475​$$$
Hence
$$$P(x)=−262295​x3+2647685​x2+13475​x​$$$


Differentiating $P(x)$ with respect to $x$, we get
$$$P′(x)=−266885​x2+1347685​x+13475​​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $P(x)$, the maximum profit occurs at point
A.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/01769894-ccf2-4567-9e25-00dfe1fa2901/5541c9fa3d0d1b43403859281edadfc0d340eef4.svg)


Using G.D.C. to find the coordinates of A, we get
$$$x=13.9, and P(x)≈118000$$$
Hence,
The maximum profit will occur when the owner buys
$13900​$ souvenirs.
The resulting profit will be approximately
$$118000.​$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
A company manufactures cement, lime and mortar for construction projects. This question considers the validity of the company's claims regarding the weights of their products.
Lime mortar is a mixture used in construction to reduce moisture in masonry. The mixture contains cement, lime and sand in the ratio $a:b:c$, where $a+b+c=17$.
Cement costs $$0.50$ per kilogram, lime costs $$2.75$ per kilogram and sand costs $$0.06$ per kilogram.
Frank and Kevin have separately purchased $5a$ kilograms of cement, $5b$ kilograms of lime and $5c$ kilograms of sand each for their respective construction projects, in the correct ratio. They have made their purchases at different shops and therefore they have been charged different prices.
The following table shows how much Frank and Kevin were charged per kilogram for each product, and the total amount they had to pay.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a98d123f-26a9-4287-a7fa-a3cc772e4d50/images/cd897c39-7e85-46b7-aed8-ada41f27dcdc/1169a.JPG)






Determine a matrix equation of the form $Ax=b$ to represent the information given above.[2]



Hence, find the values of $a,b$ and $c$.[2]





The cement is sold in $10$kg bags. The manufacturer claims that the weights of the bags, $C$, are such that $C∼N(10.2,0.12)$.

Calculate the probability that a randomly selected bag weighs less than $10$kg. Give your answer to four significant figures.[2]


Bena needs a total of 200 kilograms and is given two options by the manufacturer.
Option one: Twenty of the $10$kg bags so that $T1​=C1​+C2​+⋯+C20​$
Option two: A single $200$kg “mega-bag” such that $T2​=20C$.


Determine


The distribution of $T1​$ .[3]



$P(T1​>200)$[1]





Determine


The distribution of $T2​$ .[3]



$P(T2​>200)$[1]





State which option Bena should choose, giving a reason.[1]



Bena chooses option one. She suspects that the manufacturer’s claim is incorrect. To test this hypothesis, she weighs all twenty bags. If more than two bags weigh less than $10$kg, she will reject the manufacturer’s claim.

Calculate the significance level of Bena’s hypothesis test.[3]


Bena finds that nine of her bags weigh less than $10$kg and lays a complaint with the manufacturer. The manufacturer concedes that they made an error, and while the mean weight of their bags is $10.2$ kg, in their claim they had accidentally written the variance as $0.12$, when it was in fact $0.1$.


Given this new information, find the probability that Bena could have made a type II error in her hypothesis test.[3]



If Bena had conducted her original hypothesis test with the correct information from the manufacturer, at the significance level found in part (f), determine the critical region for the test.[3]
